audio.descriptors
Class AudioDescriptor

java.lang.Object
  audio.descriptors.AudioDescriptor

public class AudioDescriptor
extends Object

AudioDescriptor is the class that contains all the functions that provide low-level audio signal features. These features give useful information when you want to analyze a digital audio signal. Audio Descriptors can be used for many purposes, such as: - Speech Recognition - Music Information Retrieval applications - Mood Detection – Event Detection - Pitch Tracking This class works with Minim AudioSource objects, i.e. AudioInput, AudioOutput, AudioPlayer and AudioSample.

+Example
import template.library.*;

HelloLibrary hello;

void setup() {
  size(400,400);
  smooth();
  
  hello = new HelloLibrary(this);
  
  PFont font = createFont("",40);
  textFont(font);
}

void draw() {
  background(0);
  fill(255);
  text(hello.sayHello(), 40, 200);
}

getRightBrightness

public float getRightBrightness(AudioSource x)
The spectral brightness is defined as the amount of energy in the spectrum starting from a specified cutoff frequency (in this case 1500 Hz), divided by the total energy of the signal spectrum

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
b Spectral brightness coefficient

getRightCentroid

public float getRightCentroid(AudioSource x)
The spectral centroid is the baricenter of the spectrum; it is calculated as the weighted mean of the frequencies present in the signal, with their magnitude as the weights. The result is expressed in Hertz [Hz]

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
asc Audio Spectral Centroid measured in Hertz [Hz]

getRightEntropy

public float getRightEntropy(AudioSource x)
The Spectral Entropy is computed as the Shannon’s entropy of the signal spectrum. The entropy is divided by the logarithm of the length N of the spectrum in order to have a result which is independent from the windowing length.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
ent Spectral Entropy coefficient

getRightFlatness

public float getRightFlatness(AudioSource x)
Spectral flatness provides a way to quantify how tone-like a sound is, as opposed to being noise-like. The meaning of tonal in this context is in the sense of the amount of peaks or resonant structure in a power spectrum, as opposed to flat spectrum of a white noise.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
asf Spectral Flatness coefficient

getRightFlux

public float getRightFlux(AudioSource x)
Spectral flux is a measure of how quickly the power spectrum of a signal is changing, calculated by comparing the power spectrum of half a frame against the power spectrum of the other half.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
flux Spectral Flux coefficient

getRightHR

public float getRightHR(AudioSource x)
The harmonic ratio (HR) is a measure of the proportion of harmonic components in the power spectrum. It is in practice a coefficient associated to each signal frame, computed as the maximum value of the autocorrelation function.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
hr Harmonic Ratio coefficient

getRightInharmonicity

public float getRightInharmonicity(AudioSource x)
Inharmonicity estimates the amount of partials that are not multiples of the fundamental frequency. It is computed by considering the ideal locations of harmonics vs the actual harmonics in a spectrum. In this implementation, a lower value implies a more harmonic signal.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
inh Inharmonicity coefficient

getRightFundFreq

public float getRightFundFreq(AudioSource x)
This function computes the fundamental frequency of the examined signal.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
f0 Fundamental Frequency measured in Hertz [Hz]
See Also:
Pitch Detection algorithm

getRightIrregularity

public float getRightIrregularity(AudioSource x)
The irregularity of a spectrum is the degree of variation of the successive peaks of the spectrum. It is computed as the sum of the square of the difference in amplitude between adjoining partials.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
irr Spectral Irregularity coefficient

getRightKurtosis

public float getRightKurtosis(AudioSource x)
The kurtosis gives a measure of the flatness of the spectrum around its mean value. It is computed from the 4th order of the moment.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
kurt Spectral kurtosis coefficient

getRightMFCC

public float getRightMFCC(AudioSource x,
                          int index)
Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) originate from automatic speech recognition. The MFCCs are to some extent created according to the principles of the human auditory system, but also to be a compact representation of the amplitude spectrum and with considerations of the computational complexity.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
index - The order of the MFCC to be computed (usually 1 ≤ index ≤ 13)
Returns:
melCoeff The index-th order Mel Cepstral coefficient
See Also:
Mel filterbank algorithm

getRightSpread

public float getRightSpread(AudioSource x)
The spectrum spread is also called instantaneous bandwidth; it is defined as the second central moment (i.e. the variance) of spectrum.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
ass The Audio Spectrum Spread coefficient

getRightSTE

public float getRightSTE(AudioSource x)
Short Time Energy (STE) expresses the instant energy of each frame, and is commonly known as volume. A speech audio sample will give large variations in the STE-values. Music has much shorter pauses, or no pauses, and will therefore have a more constant STE-level.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
ste Short Time Energy coefficient

getRightZCR

public int getRightZCR(AudioSource x)
The zero-crossing rate is the rate of sign-changes along a signal, i.e., the rate at which the signal changes from positive to negative or back.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
z The amount of sign-changes within the signal

getRightSkewness

public float getRightSkewness(AudioSource x)
The skewness gives a measure of the asymmetry of the spectrum around its mean value. It is computed from the 3rd order of the moment.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
skew Spectral Skewness coefficient

getRightRoughness

public float getRightRoughness(AudioSource x)
The roughness of a signal is related to the beating phenomena between the peaks of its spectrum. An estimation of the total roughness can be obtained by computing the peaks of the spectrum, and taking the average of all the dissonance between all possible pairs of peaks.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
r Roughness coefficient

getFundFreq

public float getFundFreq(AudioSource x)
This function computes the fundamental frequency of the examined signal.

Parameters:
x - The time-domain signal to be analyzed
Returns:
f0 Fundamental Frequency measured in Hertz [Hz]
See Also:
Pitch Detection algorithm
+Example
/**
 * Instant Pitch
 * by Davide Totaro.
 *  
 * This sketch demonstrates how to use the getFundFrequency method 
 * of AudioDescriptor, a class totally compatible with standard 
 * Minim library.
 * The getFundFrequency method allows you to extract the Fundamental 
 * Frequency from the mix/code> channel of anAudioPlayer 
 * object. The returned value is measured in Hertz [Hz].
 * 
 * Every AudioDescriptor function receives as input an AudioSource 
 * object, like AudioPlayer.
 */

import ddf.minim.*;
import ddf.minim.analysis.*;

import audio.descriptors.*;

// define Minim objects
Minim minim;
AudioInput in;
FFT f;
int N;  // number of spectrum components

// define AudioDescriptor object
AudioDescriptor ad;

// declare and initialize constant values
final int mulFactor = 11;

void setup(){
  size(512, 200, P2D);

  minim = new Minim(this);
  minim.debugOn();
  
  // get a line in from Minim, default bit depth is 16
  in = minim.getLineIn(Minim.STEREO, 512);
  
  // create and set the FFT object
  f = new FFT(in.bufferSize(), in.sampleRate());
  f.window(FFT.HAMMING);
  N = f.specSize();
  
  // create Audio Descriptor through constructor
  ad = new AudioDescriptor();
  
}//end setup

void draw(){
  background(0);
  stroke(255);
  
  // compute the frequency components of the input signal
  f.forward(in.mix);
  
  // draw the spectrum
  for(int i = 0; i < N - 1; i++){
    line(i*2, height - 5, i*2, height - 5 - f.getBand(i) * mulFactor);
  }
  
  // compute the Fundamental Frequency of the input mix channel.
  // this value is measured in Hertz [Hz].
  // show it on the spectrum with a different color.
  float f0 = ad.getFundFreq(in);
  stroke(11,11,222);
  int k0 = f.freqToIndex(f0);  // convert the frequency from Hertz into FFT index
  line(k0*2, height - 11, k0*2, height - 11 - f.getBand(k0) * mulFactor);
}//end draw


void stop(){
  in.close();
  minim.stop();
  
  super.stop();
}

The irregularity of a spectrum is the degree of variation of the successive peaks of the spectrum. It is computed as the sum of the square of the difference in amplitude between adjoining partials.

The roughness of a signal is related to the beating phenomena between the peaks of its spectrum. An estimation of the total roughness can be obtained by computing the peaks of the spectrum, and taking the average of all the dissonance between all possible pairs of peaks.

Parameters:

Returns:
r Roughness coefficient
+Example
/**
 * Charleston Detection
 * by Davide Totaro.
 *  
 * This sketch demonstrates how to use the getRoughness method 
 * of AudioDescriptor, a class totally compatible with standard 
 * Minim library.
 * The getRoughness method allows you to extract the Roughness 
 * coefficient from the mix/code> channel of anAudioPlayer 
 * object. The returned value is contained between 0 and 1.
 * 
 * Every AudioDescriptor function receives as input an AudioSource 
 * object, like AudioPlayer.
 */

import ddf.minim.*;
import audio.descriptors.*;

// define Minim objects
AudioPlayer player;
Minim minim;

// define AudioDescriptor object
AudioDescriptor ad;

// declare and initialize constant values
final float mulFactor = 40;
final int rad = 111;  // radius
final float thresholdValue = 0.055;

void setup(){
  size(512, 200, P2D);

  minim = new Minim(this);
  // load a file, give the AudioPlayer buffers that are 1024 samples long
  player = minim.loadFile("groove.mp3");
  
  // play the file
  player.play();
  
  // create Audio Descriptor through constructor
  ad = new AudioDescriptor();
  
  // drawing parameters
  noStroke();
  fill(222, 111, 0);
  smooth();
}//end setup

void draw(){
  background(0);
  
  // compute the Roughness coefficient of the player mix channel and
  // detect the charleston sound.
  // since this value will be between 0 and 1, we use an exponential
  // function in order to better show its effects
  float rough = ad.getRoughness(player);
  if(rough > thresholdValue){  // Roughness coefficient greater than predefined threshold
    ellipse(width/2, height/2, rad + exp(rough*mulFactor), rad + exp(rough*mulFactor));
  }
  else{
    ellipse(width/2, height/2, rad, rad);
  }
}//end draw

void stop(){
  player.close();
  minim.stop();
  
  super.stop();
}
